key_points: Norsk Hydro, a Norwegian renewable energy and aluminum manufacturing company, faced a ransomware attack in 2019.
Despite the attack crippling its network, Norsk Hydro refused to pay the ransom demanded by hackers.
The attack occurred on the same day Hilde Merete Aasheim was appointed as CEO of Norsk Hydro.
The attack locked out users from over 3,000 servers and thousands of PCs, encrypting key areas of the IT network.
Norsk Hydro opted to work with cybersecurity experts and manually handle operations to avoid paying the ransom.
The company experienced significant operational disruptions, leading to an estimated loss of $70 million.
Production was maintained through manual processes, including pen and paper, for about three weeks.
Hilde Merete Aasheim and CIO Jo De Vliegher led the recovery efforts, with help from Microsoft and the Norwegian National Cyber Security Centre.
The incident led to a major reevaluation of Norsk Hydro's cybersecurity measures and priorities.
The U.S. Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) advises against paying ransoms, noting it fuels the criminal economy.
spokespersons: Eric Goldstein (Official, U.S. Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency)
